abstract.text: A control that defines an area on the screen that a user clicks to trigger an action.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Buttons are a standard control for initiating actions within your app. You can configure buttons with many different visual styles, but the behavior is the same. When a user clicks it, a button calls the action method of its associated target object. (If you configure a button as continuous, it calls its action method at timed intervals until the user releases the mouse button or the cursor leaves the button boundaries). You use the action method to perform your app-specific tasks.
There are multiple types of buttons, each with a different user interface and behavior. The
class defines the button types, and calling the
If you configure it as an accelerator button (type
), you can set a button to send action messages when changes in pressure occur when the user clicks the button.
Buttons can either have two states (on and off) or three states (on, off, and mixed). You enable a three-state button by calling the

method. On and off (also referred to as alternate and normal) states indicate that the user clicked or didn’t click the button. Mixed is typically used for checkboxes or radio buttons, which allow for an additional intermediate state. For example, suppose the state of a checkbox denotes whether a text field contains bold text. If all text in the text field is bold, then the checkbox is on. If none of the text is bold, then the checkbox is off. If some of the text is bold, then the checkbox is mixed.
For most types of buttons, the value of the button matches its state—the value is
for mixed. For pressure-sensitive buttons, the value of the button indicates pressure level instead.
both provide a control view, which displays an

object. However, while a matrix requires you to access the button cell objects directly, most button class methods act as “covers” for identically declared button cell methods. In other words, the implementation of the button method invokes the corresponding button cell method for you, allowing you to be unconcerned with the existence of the button cell. The only button cell methods that don’t have covers relate to the font you use to display the key equivalent and to specific methods for highlighting or showing the state of the button.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A button that sends an action when the user first clicks the button and continues sending actions until the user releases pressure entirely.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary for an accessibility element to act as a button.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A control that defines an area on the screen that a user clicks to trigger an action.
The compression options active for this button.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the button allows a mixed state.
An alternate image that appears on the button when the button is in an on state.
The title that the button displays when the button is in an on state.
The title that the button displays as an attributed string when the button is in an on state.
The title that the button displays in an off state, as an attributed string.
The color of the button’s bezel, in appearances that support it.
The appearance of the button’s border.
Sets the priority compression options for this button.
A tint color to use for the template image and text content.
Returns by reference the delay and interval periods for a continuous button.
A Boolean value that defines whether a button’s action has a destructive effect.
Highlights (or unhighlights) the button.
The image that appears on the button when it’s in an off state, or
if there is no such image.
A Boolean value that determines how the button’s image and title are positioned together within the button bezel.
The position of the button’s image relative to its title.
The scaling mode applied to make the cell’s image fit the frame of the image view.
Creates a standard checkbox with the title you specify.
Creates a standard push button with the image you specify.
Creates a standard radio button with the title you specify.
Creates a standard push button with a title and image.
Creates a standard push button with the title you specify.
A Boolean value that determines whether the button has a border.
A Boolean value that indicates whether spring loading is enabled for the button.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the button is transparent.
The key-equivalent character of the button.
The mask specifying the modifier keys for the button’s key equivalent.
An integer value indicating the maximum pressure level for a button of type
Returns the minimum size of the button by using the compression options.
Checks the button’s key equivalent against the specified event and, if they match, simulates the button being clicked.
Sets the button’s type, which affects its user interface and behavior when clicked.
Sets the button to its next state.
Sets the message delay and interval periods for a continuous button.
Sets the title of a button with a character denoting an access key.
A Boolean value that determines whether the button displays its border only when the pointer is over it.
The sound that plays when the user clicks the button.
The button’s state.
The combination of point size, weight, and scale to use when sizing and displaying symbol images.
The title displayed on the button when it’s in an off state.
An object that defines the user interface of a button or other clickable region of a view.
A control that displays a color value and lets the user change that color value.
A button with a pull-down menu and a default action.
A specialized view, such as a button or text field, that notifies your app of relevant events using the target-action design pattern.
A constant for specifying the position of a button’s image relative to its title.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
A display of image data in a frame.
A visual representation of a level or quantity, using discrete values.
A legacy interface for grouping radio buttons or other types of cells together.

A multilevel accelerator button is a variation of a normal accelerator button that allows for a configurable number of stepped pressure levels. As each one is reached, the user receives light tactile feedback and an action is sent.
A control for selecting an item from a list.
A defined set of rules that allows the editing of predicate objects.
An interface that provides visual feedback to the user about the status of an ongoing task.
An interface for configuring a rule-based list of options.
Display one or more buttons in a single horizontal group.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
The appearance and behavior of an item in the systemwide menu bar.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A protocol that describes how a UI control should redisplay when space is restricted.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A protocol that a custom class can adopt to manage the enabled state of a UI element.
Display a list of values in a pop-up menu that lets the user select a value or type in a custom value.
Display a calendar date and provide controls for editing the date value.
A display of a file system path or virtual path information.
Provide a text field that is optimized for text-based search interfaces.
Display a range of values from which the user selects a single value.
Handle user input by connecting buttons, sliders, and other controls to your app’s code using the target-action design pattern.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Responding to control-based events using target-action

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
